title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of an Online Small-Group Self-Management Workshop for Rural Caregivers of Individuals With Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias
description_brief:
Rural caregivers face challenges of geographic isolation and lower health care access and quality. Many rural dementia caregivers experience serious health consequences due to caregiving responsibilities that can limit their ability to maintain their caregiving role. Thus, there is a pressing need for effective, scalable, and accessible programs to support rural dementia caregivers.

Online programs offer a convenient and readily translatable option for program delivery because they can be accessed by caregivers in the home and at the convenience of the user. Building Better Caregivers is an online 6-week, interactive, small-group self-management, social support, and skills-building workshop developed for caregivers of individuals with Alzheimer's disease or related dementia.

The investigators will conduct a hybrid effectiveness-implementation randomized controlled trial that will enroll and randomize 640 rural dementia caregivers into two groups: the intervention (workshop) group and the attention control group. Caregivers will be recruited throughout the United States. Primary outcomes will be caregiver stress and depressive symptoms. The investigators hypothesize that stress scores and depressive symptoms will be significantly improved at 12 months in the intervention group versus control group. The investigators will also identify key strengths (facilitators) and weaknesses (barriers) of workshop implementation. The investigators will use the RE-AIM implementation framework and a mixed methods approach to identify implementation characteristics pertinent to both caregivers and rural community organizations.

If the Building Better Caregivers workshop is proven to be effective, this research has the potential to open new research horizons, particularly on how to reach and effectively support isolated dementia caregivers in rural areas with an intervention that is scalable, even in low-resourced settings. If the workshop can achieve its goals with rural dementia caregivers, some of those most isolated, it would also be expected to be scalable in other low-resourced settings (e.g., in urban or suburban environments).

groups.title: Building Better Caregivers Workshop Group
groups.description: The Building Better Caregivers Workshop is a 6-week online small group workshop. Participants received self-management and caregiving skills-building training and social support. They also received a workbook to keep.

groups.title: Attention Control Group
groups.description: Attention control group participants received two 15-30 minutes phone calls and a handbook on dementia and caregiver resources.

milestones.type: Group Delivery Begins = Modified Intention to Treat Population

dropWithdraws.type: Administratively removed prior to group delivery: unable to verify identify, duplicate, PLWD death
Planned study completion at 6-months. 2 final cohorts initiated with known follow up of 6 months.

groups.title: Building Better Caregivers Workshop Group
groups.description: The Building Better Caregivers Workshop is a 6-week online small group workshop. Participants received self-management and caregiving skills-building training and social support. They also received a workbook to keep.

groups.title: Attention Control Group
groups.description: Attention control group participants received two 15-30 minutes phone calls and a handbook on dementia and caregiver resources.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

measures.title: Age, Continuous
measures.populationDescription: Two participants in each group did not answer the age question.

measures.title: PHQ-8
measures.description: Depressive symptoms were measured using the 8-item Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8), with score range 0-24 (higher score indicates worse depressive symptoms).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Stress
measures.description: Stress was measured using the single-item visual numeric stress scale, with score range 0-10 (higher score indicates worse stress).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Caregiver Self-Efficacy
measures.description: Caregiving self-efficacy was measured with the Caregiver Self-Efficacy scale (8 items), with score range, 1-10 (higher score indicates greater self-efficacy). The scale was not administered at follow-up assessments if caregivers reported that they were not providing caregiving at that time.
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Zarit Care Burden
measures.description: Care burden was measured with the Zarit Burden Interview (12 items), with score range, 0-24 (higher score indicates greater burden). The scale was not administered at follow-up assessments if caregivers reported that they were not providing caregiving at that time.
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Self-Rated General Health
measures.description: Poor self-rated health was measured using the single item Short Form Survey (SF-1) scale, with score range, 1-5 (higher score indicates worse health).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Loneliness
measures.description: Loneliness was measured with the UCLA loneliness scale (3 items), with score range, 3-9 (higher score indicates greater loneliness).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Social Isolation
measures.description: Social network was measured with the Lubben social network scale (6 items), with score range, 0-30 (higher score indicates greater network).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Healthcare Utilization
measures.description: Healthcare utilization days was measured as emergency room and hospitalization days of use in the prior six months as a count, with range 0-180 days (higher count indicates more days).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

measures.title: Person with Dementia General Health (caregiver reported)
measures.description: Poor self-rated health was measured using the single item Short Form Survey (SF-1) scale, with score range, 1-5 (higher score indicates worse health).
measures.populationDescription: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

outcomeMeasures.title: Personal Health Questionnaire Depression (PHQ-8) Scale Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Personal Health Questionnaire Depression (PHQ-8) scale. The scale score is calculated by summing each item to produce a total score between 0 and 24, with higher scores indicating worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Short Caregiver Self-Efficacy Scale Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Short Caregiver Self-Efficacy scale (8-items). The scale scores is calculated by taking the mean of the items to produce a total score between 1 and 10, with higher scores indicating better outcome.

groups.description: The Building Better Caregivers Workshop is a 6-week online small group workshop. Participants received self-management and caregiving skills-building training and social support. They also received a workbook to keep.

outcomeMeasures.title: Zarit Burden Interview-12 (ZBI-12) Scale Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Short form of the Zarit Burden Interview-12 (ZBI-12) scale (12-items). The scale score is calculated by summing each item to produce a total score between 0 and 24, with higher scores indicating worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) measure SF-1 self-rated general health single item. The scale score ranges from 1 to 5, with higher scores indicating worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Lubben Social Isolation Scale Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Lubben Social isolation scale (6-items). The scale score is calculated by summing each item to produce a total score between 0 and 30, with lower scores indicating worse outcome.

groups.title: Building Better Caregivers Workshop Group
groups.description: The Building Better Caregivers Workshop is a 6-week online small group workshop. Participants received self-management and caregiving skills-building training and social support. They also received a workbook to keep.

groups.title: Attention Control Group
groups.description: Attention control group participants received two 15-30 minutes phone calls and a handbook on dementia and caregiver resources.

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Health Care Utilization
outcomeMeasures.description: 3-items measuring days of overnight hospitalizations, nursing home or other long-term care facility use, and hospital emergency room visits from the Health and Retirement Study, modified time frame from self-report for past 12 months to self-report for past 6 months; scored as single items; with higher scores indicating worse outcome. Scores range from 0-180.

groups.description: The Building Better Caregivers Workshop is a 6-week online small group workshop. Participants received self-management and caregiving skills-building training and social support. They also received a workbook to keep.

outcomeMeasures.title: Person With Dementia General Health Score as Reported by Caregiver
outcomeMeasures.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) measure SF-1 caregiver-reported general health single item. The scale score ranges from 1 to 5, with higher scores indicating worse outcome.

seriousEvents.notes: One death unrelated to the study occurred (i.e., an "act of God" event). During a state of emergency caused by massive rainstorms and flooding, a tree fell onto the roof of the participant's house and crushed her when she was in bed asleep.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Randomization occurred 2 weeks before group delivery to allow for mailing of books and scheduling calls. During this run-in period 9 participants were administratively dropped: 4 in intervention group, due to death of person with dementia (2), being a duplicate (1), and inability to verify identity (1); 5 in control group, due to death of their person (3), death of caregiver in natural disaster (1), and being paid caregiver (1). Thus, the modified ITT analysis included 409 participants.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a 6‑week online small‑group self‑management and support workshop (Building Better Caregivers) delivered to rural dementia caregivers to reduce caregiver stress and depressive symptoms — this is a psychosocial/behavioral support intervention, not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search3turn0search4

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description and registry/protocol: it is a hybrid effectiveness‑implementation randomized controlled trial of the Building Better Caregivers online workshop (6 weeks, small‑group), enrolling rural dementia caregivers with primary outcomes of caregiver stress and depressive symptoms (trial registered NCT04428112; study protocol published). No pharmacologic agent, biologic, or small‑molecule is involved. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — per the provided category definitions, this study does not test a disease‑targeted biologic, disease‑targeted small molecule, a cognitive enhancer, nor an intervention aimed at patient neuropsychiatric symptoms; it targets caregiver well‑being via a behavioral/implementation intervention, so 'N/A' is the appropriate category. Supporting/related references: prior evaluations and descriptions of Building Better Caregivers and the online workshop are available (pilot and pragmatic trials, program website). citeturn0search5turn0search0turn0search4
